Hi guys, for some reason, I need the circular order structure on Fin n. But there is something confusing me: when the endpoints of a circular interval are equal, should I define btw to be True and sbtw to be False?

More precisely, the definition of circular order requires btw_total : ∀ (a b c : α), btw a b c ∨ btw c b a, so when a = c, this property means btw a b a always holds for any b. This really makes sense because we can view the circular interval both as a single point from one direction and as a loop from the other direction.

The definition also requires sbtw_iff_btw_not_btw : ∀ {a b c : α}, sbtw a b c ↔ btw a b c ∧ ¬btw c b a, so when a = c, this property means sbtw a b a is always false. And at this time, we cannot use the same viewpoint as above (i.e. from both directions).

Definition of circular order in mathlib: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Circular.html#CircularOrder.

Thanks in advance!
Doesn't your argument answer your own question? Indeed we have these theorems already: see docs#btw_rfl_left_right and docs#sbtw_irrefl_left_right , so you're exactly right!
LizBonn has marked this topic as resolved.
